name: Healthcare Patient Portal - Complete Double Diamond
description: Full Double Diamond for improving healthcare patient portal usability with focus on health information comprehension and empowerment

inputs.context: Healthcare provider's patient portal has low adoption (35% of patients) and poor satisfaction. Patients struggle to understand medical information, book appointments, and manage prescriptions. Goal: increase portal usage to 70% and improve patient health outcomes through better engagement
inputs.initialResearch: Patient interviews (n=40), healthcare provider interviews (n=15), usability testing sessions, analysis of support tickets and abandonment points

userInsights.insight: Patients can't understand medical terminology in test results and notes
userInsights.evidence: 78% of patients report not understanding their test results. Most common support request is 'What does this mean?'
userInsights.userQuote: My cholesterol is 185. Is that good? Bad? The note says 'within normal limits' but I don't know what's normal

userInsights.insight: Booking appointments requires too many steps and medical knowledge patients don't have
userInsights.evidence: 62% appointment booking abandonment rate. Users stuck on 'select visit type' dropdown with 30 medical options
userInsights.userQuote: I don't know if I need a 'consultation' or an 'evaluation' or a 'follow-up visit'. I just want to see my doctor about my knee pain

userInsights.insight: Patients feel disempowered and confused by medical system, portal reinforces this
userInsights.evidence: Patients describe feeling 'stupid', 'overwhelmed', 'like an outsider' when using portal
userInsights.userQuote: The portal makes me feel like I'm not smart enough to understand my own health. It's written for doctors, not for me

problemAreas.description: Medical jargon and clinical language makes information inaccessible to patients
problemAreas.userImpact: Patients can't make informed decisions, feel anxious, call provider for explanations, disengage from portal

problemAreas.description: Common tasks like booking appointments require medical knowledge patients lack
problemAreas.userImpact: High abandonment rates, patients call instead of using portal, frustration

problemAreas.description: Portal design reinforces power imbalance between patients and medical system
problemAreas.userImpact: Low engagement, patients feel disempowered, reduced health outcomes

problemStatement.statement: Patients using healthcare portals struggle to understand their medical information and take action on their health because portals use clinical language designed for providers rather than patients, resulting in disengagement, anxiety, unnecessary phone calls, and worse health outcomes
problemStatement.who: Patients of all health literacy levels
problemStatement.what: Struggle to understand medical information and take health actions
problemStatement.why: Clinical language and provider-centric design creates comprehension barriers
problemStatement.where: Throughout patient portal experience, especially test results and appointment booking
problemStatement.when: Every time patients access their health information
problemStatement.impact: 35% portal adoption, 78% don't understand results, 62% appointment booking abandonment

designPrinciples.rationale: Patients need to understand before they can act. Start with plain language, offer technical details for those who want them
examples: Explain medical terms in tooltips and expandable sections
Use 6th-8th grade reading level for primary content
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: May oversimplify for medically sophisticated patients, but they can access details

designPrinciples.rationale: Patients own their health data. Design should empower action, not create barriers
examples: Ask 'What brings you in?' not 'Select visit type: Consultation vs. Evaluation'
Proactive suggestions: 'Based on your results, you might want to...'
Remove unnecessary medical jargon from action items
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: Requires more sophisticated routing logic and provider workflow changes

designPrinciples.rationale: Numbers without context are meaningless. Always explain what data means for the patient
examples: Show test results on visual scale: Low ← Healthy → High
Compare to patient's previous results and trends
Explain 'what this means for you' for every result
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: More screen space needed, more complex data presentation

successCriteria.measurement: % of patients who have logged in within past 90 days
Post-viewing survey: 'I understood my test results'
Calls asking 'What does this result mean?'

concepts.name: Visual Health Timeline
concepts.description: Replace tables of test results with visual timeline showing health trends and milestones
concepts.howItWorks: Test results displayed on visual timeline with trend lines, color coding (healthy/attention needed), and plain language explanations. Timeline shows health journey over time
strengths: Makes trends obvious at a glance
Tells story of patient's health journey
weaknesses: May not work well on mobile

concepts.name: Plain Language Layer
concepts.description: Two-layer system: plain language default with medical details available via toggle
concepts.howItWorks: Primary view shows plain language explanations. Toggle switch reveals medical terminology and clinical details. Patients choose their preferred view
weaknesses: Toggle might be missed by users

concepts.name: Intelligent Appointment Assistant
concepts.description: Conversational interface asks plain language questions to route appointment booking
concepts.howItWorks: Instead of medical dropdowns, ask: 'What brings you in today?' System interprets and routes to appropriate visit type and provider. Confirms understanding

concepts.name: Personalized Health Coach
concepts.description: AI coach explains test results, suggests actions, answers questions in plain language
concepts.howItWorks: Virtual health coach reviews results with patient, explains in plain language, suggests follow-up actions, answers questions. Available 24/7 via chat

selectedSolution.name: Patient-First Portal
selectedSolution.description: Combined solution using visual health timeline, plain language layer, and intelligent appointment assistant to make portal accessible and empowering
selectedSolution.rationale: Combines visual communication, plain language, and smart routing to address comprehension and empowerment problems. Visual timeline makes trends obvious, plain language removes barriers, intelligent assistant eliminates medical jargon from booking
selectedSolution.valueProposition: Understand your health and take action, without needing a medical degree
differentiators: Only portal with visual health journey timeline
Plain language as default, not afterthought
Book appointments by describing your problem, not medical codes

keyFeatures.description: Primary view of test results as visual timeline with trend lines, color-coded status, and plain language summaries
keyFeatures.userBenefit: See health trends at a glance without interpreting numbers

keyFeatures.description: Every test result includes plain language explanation of what it means and what to do
Natural language interface for appointment booking - describe problem, system routes appropriately
keyFeatures.userBenefit: Book appointments without medical terminology knowledge

implementationSteps.description: Implement plain language layer across all portal content
deliverables: Plain language content for common test results
successCriteria: All common results have plain language explanations

implementationSteps.description: Build visual timeline interface for test results
successCriteria: Users can view health trends visually

qualityAssurance.testingStrategy: Extensive usability testing with diverse patient populations including elderly, low health literacy, and disabled patients
userTesting: Usability testing with 40 patients across literacy levels
Comprehension testing of plain language content
A/B test visual timeline vs. table view
